15.65.text:
>> Hello, I'm Vikki Cooper from
the GRCC English department.

22.29.text:
And I have the honor of
interviewing Dr. Consuela Ward.

27.26.text:
Dr. Consuela Ward
is the author of...

32.90.text:
And she has more than 20 years
experience as an educator,

39.51.text:
and coach on diversity
and inclusion topics.

46.38.text:
>> Yes, thank you so much.
>> Yes, I'm so happy--

48.18.text:
>> Glad to be here.
>> Yeah, I'm happy
to have you here.

50.72.text:
I have to start
off with your poem.

53.15.text:
And you started your
book off with a poem,

57.22.text:
and I was hoping you
could read the poem.

58.99.text:
>> Sure!
>> Do you mind reading it?

62.80.text:
And then, I have
a question.

64.13.text:
>> Okay, so it's so funny,
you asking me to read it.

68.70.text:
I am going to explain
the poem tonight.

71.00.text:
>> Okay.
>> And I'll be glad to explain

73.27.text:
parts of it
here, as well.

75.24.text:
But it's called
"The Cut That Won't Heal."

79.38.text:
"I got a cut that
won't heal.

82.38.text:
"It's that burdenous
split between my thighs.

85.82.text:
"It bleeds from the pain
of yesterday and today.

89.42.text:
"We gotta teach our daughters
how to heal for their tomorrow.

99.33.text:
"My superpowers endured
inherited servitude with grace

111.85.text:
"I had hoped to survive
its reign of oppression.

114.95.text:
"But never considered the
freedom to escape it.

122.02.text:
"we all bleed red
in the cut.

127.39.text:
"from the swelling of physical
and psychological rape.

133.10.text:
"mutilate my wound deeper to
appease their weak minds.

137.74.text:
"Men with laws confuse
their interests with mine,

146.48.text:
"causing natural disasters
on land and sea.

152.09.text:
"the sun sending flashes
of heat from the sky.

155.29.text:
"oceans of tears flow
from years of neglect.

159.23.text:
"But they rebuild and
profit off of my hysteria

162.93.text:
"by removing the decaying
pieces of womb scattered about.

167.77.text:
"I got a cut that
just won't heal.

170.40.text:
"It's that burdenous
split between my thighs.

174.01.text:
"It bleeds from the pain
of yesterday and today.

176.61.text:
"Let's empower our
daughters to heal today."

183.45.text:
>> I read that you wrote this
while you were in the Bahamas.

185.95.text:
>> Yes.
>> Taking a break
in the Bahamas.

189.29.text:
two weeks there.
>> Well-needed break, right?

193.13.text:
>> This poem-- can you
explain the significance

196.56.text:
that it has for our
daughters, for our girls,

202.67.text:
so when I talk about
that burden, right?

208.04.text:
So we have to learn
how to embrace it,

211.41.text:
and use it to
empower ourselves.

214.21.text:
I think, in my recollection, I
realize how when we are living

219.82.text:
in a culture that's centered
on the pleasure of men

228.49.text:
and what our
purposes are, right?

231.80.text:
And I want us to be
able to recognize it,

236.87.text:
to believe that it's
natural and okay.

239.81.text:
>> Yes.
>> And I serve to
challenge that.

243.11.text:
You know, my mother
may have taught me

245.61.text:
how to be
obligated to men...

248.18.text:
and to the things that serve
men, including religion.

253.02.text:
But she could only
teach me what she knew.

257.26.text:
hopefully you do better.
>> That's right.

259.33.text:
>> And so, I wanna be able to
do better for the young women

266.40.text:
>> One more question in
regards to this poem.

269.20.text:
And it reminded me
of how Alice Walker

277.34.text:
>> Okay.
>> You know, if you've heard

278.81.text:
the quote where she says,
"A womanist is to a feminist,

285.49.text:
>> But I was thinking about
"The Cut That Won't Heal."

287.72.text:
Can you explain-- and when
you said-- I should say this--

291.69.text:
"Elders taught obligation over
love, communal care over self."

298.93.text:
>> Do you think
that Black women

302.74.text:
>> Absolutely.
>> In order to save
the Black community?

308.51.text:
And while I am a huge
proponent of community,

312.81.text:
I'm a huge proponent of all
of us being interdependent...

319.69.text:
>> Independent.
>> You know, some of
us walk around saying,

322.02.text:
"Hey, I'm an independent
Black woman-- I'm strong."

324.99.text:
Well, I don't wear
that badge of glory.

326.76.text:
>> Mmm-hmm.
>> Not because I'm not strong.

328.96.text:
But because what you
hear without words

332.37.text:
is giving people
permission to praise you

335.60.text:
for being able to
handle the struggle...

343.68.text:
My book actually comes from
a womanist perspective.

348.01.text:
And I hope that
it's clear.

349.42.text:
I wanted to make sure
that it's clear.

353.12.text:
As far as us
being superwomen,

356.42.text:
I think I mentioned
that, as well,

357.59.text:
talking about our superpowers.
>> Oh, yes.

359.99.text:
>> You know, I am
talented, you know?

368.07.text:
And I think that by holding
onto being a superwoman,

373.04.text:
you're not allowing yourself
to feel whatever comes up

377.21.text:
for you when it
comes up, right?

381.55.text:
I think we've been conditioned
to respond meekly to pain.

384.72.text:
>> Yes, yes.
>> And I think that's sick.

389.02.text:
So I allow myself, I
give myself permission

392.63.text:
to release
when I need to,

395.76.text:
even if that makes other
people uncomfortable.

398.73.text:
I think if you can't
be your authentic self,

407.51.text:
So my next question is
about the Black church.

409.68.text:
>> Mmm!
>> We have a lot in common

411.24.text:
with the Black church.
>> I heard.

414.45.text:
>> You use the
Black church songs

419.72.text:
or the relation between
attending Black churches,

422.62.text:
white schools, which
we also have in common,

424.96.text:
and male patriarchy in your
development as a Black woman?

429.06.text:
>> So I don't know
if you noticed,

431.70.text:
but not only are there chapters
named after Black songs,

436.24.text:
if you read each
song in order

438.60.text:
in the table of contents,
it tells a story.

441.24.text:
>> It does tell a story.
>> It tells a story.

446.08.text:
But what I learned about
myself as I was reading this,

451.25.text:
and looking at patriarchy
and white supremacy

454.19.text:
and how all that
played a part...

459.99.text:
>> You know, and
during those years,

464.03.text:
I only knew to
survive it, right?

467.07.text:
And many of us never
get past only surviving...

473.17.text:
And I don't think
it's natural for you

476.78.text:
to be in survival
mode all the time.

480.08.text:
At some point, you
have to begin living.

483.32.text:
I was fortunate enough
to attend a school

489.52.text:
I don't know if
you read this part,

490.52.text:
but the only reason
I went to college

492.93.text:
is to get away
from my crazy mama.

494.36.text:
>> Yes, I remember.
>> That was it!

496.03.text:
>> In a small town.
>> In a small town, right?

499.40.text:
Went to this school 'cause
I had no place else to go

502.47.text:
and fell in love
with education.

505.34.text:
It saved my life,
you know?

507.64.text:
And so, I'm
appreciative of that.

509.58.text:
But along that journey,
there were golden nit-bits

514.18.text:
along the way to help
shape who I was, right?

518.55.text:
Some of them felt really good,
even in the Black church.

521.35.text:
So when I went
away to college,

523.36.text:
because church was so
forced on me as a kid--

533.27.text:
That I refused to go to church
for most of my college years,

536.90.text:
on purpose, but I
couldn't get away from it.

539.01.text:
Because you do what
you're conditioned to be.

542.48.text:
And so, I joined the gospel
choir while I was there.

546.51.text:
And that helped
me to cope.

549.42.text:
One thing I say about
the Black church,

551.35.text:
after I reflected was that it
both saved us and enslaved us.

557.12.text:
>> Yes, I'm so glad
you brought that up.

558.89.text:
>> Yes, and so,
it saved me

562.60.text:
because it helped
my sanity in coping.

574.71.text:
And I was
bitter for a number of years

577.41.text:
because the same message that I
heard in church hadn't changed.

580.55.text:
It was, "It's gonna be okay,
it's gonna be okay."

583.32.text:
I wanted to know
when, right?

585.65.text:
When I die, and
get to heaven?

587.15.text:
Nah, I'm not
feeling that one.

592.29.text:
>> That's-- I wanna talk more
about the Black people relying

597.86.text:
on religion in
order to survive.

601.30.text:
And then, also feeling entrapped
or enslaved by religion.

605.77.text:
So what effects do you
think it's had on,

610.74.text:
>> Well, let me say this--
first of all, I was very angry

615.31.text:
with Christianity when I
got to a certain point.

622.29.text:
I think all paths can lead
you to the same destiny

625.83.text:
that you were created for.
>> Yes.

631.06.text:
But to answer your question
about how it impacts women,

636.04.text:
I think it serves
to suppress us,

641.47.text:
Even when I read the book,
I said that it wasn't

644.21.text:
that I was trying to paint
pants on women, right?

648.15.text:
>> Right.
>> Because it's still a pig

649.72.text:
even if you put
lipstick on it.

651.38.text:
It's still a pig.
>> That's right.

653.29.text:
>> I wanted to question how it
harms us and puts us in a box.

660.59.text:
Because we are not
cookie-cutter people.

663.90.text:
We all have individual
destinies and taboos.

667.53.text:
And I wanted to
investigate that more.

670.47.text:
I think-- well, I know that
when you study the experience

675.34.text:
of Black people
in this country--

679.61.text:
because that happened here--
but there is a history

686.59.text:
is that for more
years than not,

689.59.text:
the only time men could
have titles in society

697.06.text:
And so, the deacons,
or the pastor,

705.04.text:
in our community because that's
when we could have titles.

708.41.text:
And so, even with women,
we could have some,

710.81.text:
but we can only
have so many.

714.81.text:
But again, at some point,
I got to a space

717.12.text:
where I wasn't trying to
fight for a man-made title.

721.42.text:
I had way more God
power inside of me

724.72.text:
than could ever be embodied
by a man-made title.

729.16.text:
I wrote a poem recently
called, "He Said, She Said."

733.37.text:
And it starts off and it says,
"Him-- 'Hello, my queen.'

742.44.text:
"He said, 'But let me
tell you your worth.'

752.42.text:
>> Oh, I like that.
>> Yeah, yeah.

754.65.text:
Because we have
the God power

755.96.text:
because we all come
from the same source.

759.09.text:
>> So it's more
of a spirituality

765.26.text:
>> Yeah, spirituality
is very fluid, right?

771.30.text:
I study and I practice
indigenous types

777.48.text:
>> And what I learned was
that indigenous folks

779.81.text:
all over the planet ultimately
have the same core ideas.

786.65.text:
And that's what
I focus on.

791.36.text:
>> Thank you.
>> You are very welcome.

794.39.text:
So I wanna transition and
talk about your childhood.

800.60.text:
>> Well, because
I related to this.

803.30.text:
You mentioned
that, as a child,

805.84.text:
a character on television,
Clair Huxtable.

810.41.text:
>> Yes.
>> And she was one of the few--

813.05.text:
you know, at that time,
during the '80s,

814.88.text:
where we could identify with the
Black woman who was successful.

820.55.text:
And you talked about you
wanted to emulate her,

822.96.text:
you're modeling
her life on TV.

827.69.text:
But you also said that
modeling her life on TV

831.86.text:
But then, you realized the
promised land becomes unlocked

835.70.text:
as you journey to finding
and living your purpose.

853.19.text:
>> So I think the way to do
that is to be honest with them.

858.76.text:
I think what I was concerned
about in reflection

862.46.text:
of my childhood is,
folks were not honest

865.33.text:
about what it meant
to be a woman.

870.04.text:
to do what they
couldn't do...

872.47.text:
not realizing that
it couldn't be done.

877.38.text:
And so, as I tried
to emulate Clair,

879.91.text:
one day I woke up and I realized
she wasn't even real, right?

883.98.text:
So I'm trying to
emulate her purpose

887.15.text:
rather than have several
different women

890.06.text:
that I could look up to
and take bits and pieces

895.03.text:
To help develop
my own purpose.

900.23.text:
>> Real women.
>> Women that you've read about.

901.67.text:
Women that-- not a
fictionalized character.

909.04.text:
But the women in
my community--

911.21.text:
first of all, my house in my
community was its own microcosm.

916.15.text:
because-- and this
is really important--

920.25.text:
>> Oh, so she was
from the Midwest.

921.99.text:
>> Yes.
>> That's right, and
then you moved.

923.72.text:
>> And we moved
to the South.

925.89.text:
And that difference in
region is very real.

931.00.text:
You have people moving from
the North or the Midwest,

937.24.text:
And so, I was raised by a
Northern woman in the South.

941.37.text:
You talk about contesting
all kinds of lines.

947.81.text:
>> Absolutely, because
she wasn't having it.

954.89.text:
and the kids
teased me about it,

957.49.text:
not realizing that when
Black kids go to school

961.89.text:
and they're said to be "talking
white" by other Black kids.

965.33.text:
That's part of that
intergenerational trauma

971.77.text:
where it was illegal for Black
people to read in our country--

974.84.text:
not just illegal, but
it could get you killed.

979.88.text:
There was a time where
if you were reading,

987.59.text:
"You're out of your
space and your place.

990.52.text:
"Know who you are and
what's safe for you."

993.13.text:
>> In both communities--
in the white community

1002.33.text:
So I'm gonna stay
on this issue

1006.81.text:
So now, we have more women of
color on television shows.

1011.04.text:
And who have juxtaposed this
image of Clair Huxtable

1014.28.text:
into a Cookie Lyon,
Olivia Pope,

1023.59.text:
how do we-- again, I keep
going back to our girls,

1029.06.text:
>> How do we convey,
like, the message of--

1032.00.text:
and I don't want to say
necessarily "wholesome,"

1035.23.text:
but what it means
to be a Black woman.

1037.87.text:
Because these women,
in each of these roles

1045.71.text:
And we didn't see that that
much with Clair Huxtable.

1048.11.text:
So I'm wondering how do
we convey that message

1055.35.text:
>> Mmm-hmm.
>> And in a positive message,

1059.86.text:
and not saying
that sex is wrong.

1062.43.text:
But not that you have
to be over-sexualized,

1064.66.text:
because I think that has
already happened to Black women.

1069.80.text:
>> Again, how do we-- what
do we tell our daughters

1073.47.text:
>> Right-- well, first of all,
I would say to them

1080.38.text:
but it is not a
monolithic experience.

1082.61.text:
>> Right.
>> So there are bits and pieces

1085.82.text:
of those women
that we see.

1089.02.text:
And we see them
in our community.

1091.46.text:
Even the
Mary Jane Paul ones,

1093.63.text:
sometimes, it's us
the one that got out.

1096.83.text:
>> Right.
>> So I appreciate that piece,

1103.84.text:
you can look at that
a few different ways.

1108.24.text:
white women can be
sexual, and it's okay.

1112.71.text:
Black women don't
have that same--

1114.95.text:
>> No, they don't
have that privilege.

1118.12.text:
But I am so about
being my authentic self

1122.05.text:
and writing my own story.
>> Yes.

1125.62.text:
>> So whatever that story is,
that's authentic to me--

1129.09.text:
and this is what I tell
the students that I mentee--

1131.96.text:
"Be your authentic self,
whatever that is."

1137.77.text:
>> It doesn't define you.
>> It doesn't define you, right?

1142.14.text:
It's a part of you.
>> Absolutely.

1146.55.text:
>> I remember-- I used
to be the Director

1150.12.text:
at a major university
in the South.

1152.02.text:
>> Yes.
>> And for the longest time,

1155.55.text:
I would come to
work in suits

1158.59.text:
that looked like Clair, or it
looked like Mary Jane Paul did.

1162.69.text:
And I'd had a Black student
say to me one day,

1165.76.text:
"Oh, Miss Consuela, I've
never seen a Black woman

1169.23.text:
"that has as much
power as you."

1172.50.text:
>> Just from your presence?
>> Just from my presence.

1177.51.text:
He didn't know that I
had to report to a Dean,

1181.08.text:
who reported to a
Vice President,

1184.62.text:
So I really, conceptually
of the university,

1188.59.text:
I didn't have
that much power.

1189.79.text:
But for him to see
what I did have,

1193.09.text:
that was not evident
in his community.

1195.46.text:
That child is a Principal
today, with a Doctorate.

1202.27.text:
But I had to begin
to change my story

1208.61.text:
to only put up
a facade for them,

1214.61.text:
So the suits changed
into something else.

1219.02.text:
I'd wear a suit, I'd feel
powerful, and that's great.

1222.96.text:
But that's not all I was.
>> That's right.

1226.12.text:
>> That's just
not all I was.

1227.39.text:
And that's all
that people saw.

1229.13.text:
They put me
in a box.

1231.06.text:
And then, I had to resist, once
I realized I was in this box.

1234.20.text:
And I helped
to create it!

1236.60.text:
So then, I dressed a little
bit more relaxed and cute.

1243.14.text:
>> Yes, and it was much
more comfortable for me,

1245.68.text:
and I was much
more real to them.

1247.58.text:
And even in my book, I
told them, "I'm an adult.

1252.99.text:
>> Right.
>> Right, and all
of them are lessons.

1261.93.text:
>> What do our mothers tell
us-- "Keep on living."

1263.90.text:
>> Keep on living.
>> Keep on living.

1265.63.text:
>> And don't be
afraid to experience,

1268.23.text:
but you've got to hold
onto those ancestors,

1274.17.text:
>> That's right.
>> I have a totally different

1275.77.text:
concept of what
they meant today

1280.68.text:
Because they had that
connection with spirit.

1283.98.text:
Now, I'm not talking
about the connection

1285.38.text:
that they learned in
the Black church.

1286.59.text:
>> No, no, no.
>> I'm talking about

1292.12.text:
that is hidden in
the Black church,

1295.89.text:
>> Yeah, so when we talk about
them standing on their knees.

1298.40.text:
>> Oh, yeah, that's real.
>> It is absolutely-- I agree.

1302.80.text:
>> It's calling in that energy.
>> It is.

1304.67.text:
>> It's calling in that
energy to protect you.

1313.55.text:
That reminds me-- yes,
especially our grandmothers.

1316.78.text:
So I have a couple
more questions.

1318.28.text:
And one of my favorite
quotes from your book is,

1320.39.text:
"Reclaiming my body means
having the courage to value

1324.39.text:
"in spite of doctrine
or social norms

1327.06.text:
"enough to teach people
how to treat me

1329.93.text:
"instead of brushing off
their excused behavior,

1333.37.text:
"so I can no longer trade
in white patriarchy

1344.44.text:
I just got chill bumps.
>> I read it four or five times.

1350.98.text:
>> So because for so many
years, women who look like me,

1357.52.text:
have been conditioned to
accept myths from Black men

1364.56.text:
and choose my Blackness
over my womanness.

1371.57.text:
I just choose not
to do that anymore.

1380.25.text:
And I'm not going to
pick one over the other.

1385.12.text:
And yes, you teach
people how to treat you.

1387.79.text:
I learned by saying "No,"
when you want to say "No."

1392.86.text:
We were taught to say "Yes,"
no matter what,

1395.09.text:
because we have to be
obligated to everyone else.

1407.47.text:
>> I'm gonna bring it
right back to our babies.

1410.64.text:
Once again, because you
learn how to say "No,"

1414.98.text:
and to say "No" strongly
and to not feeling guilt,

1418.28.text:
and I wonder if that
comes from maturity

1422.55.text:
or is that something that we
can teach young ladies now,

1425.92.text:
and hopefully they'll
learn that lesson.

1427.96.text:
Because I think some
of them have it.

1430.70.text:
But I watch, and I watch
our young ladies on campus.

1434.60.text:
And I see them
searching for something

1436.03.text:
other than what
they're here for.

1440.67.text:
Many of them are
searching for security.

1442.44.text:
>> Yes, I know
they are, yes.

1450.05.text:
it got to a point-- it was
real easy to just say "No"

1453.42.text:
Because I was
choosing my Blackness.

1455.45.text:
It got much harder to
say "No" to Black men...

1466.60.text:
but I've been married,
I've had my children.

1471.80.text:
Eh, now I can
really live, though.

1474.37.text:
>> Right.
